properties.media:imagetext:
EXTRACT FROM THE 70-PAGE REPORT ON A
FULL YEAR'S "METEOROLOGICAL SURVEY OF
PROPOSED SITES FOR THE SAN FRANCISCO
MUNICIPAL AIRPORT."
Weather observations started July 1, 1927, under the
direction of the San Francisco Office of
the United States
Weather Bureau.
Daily observations were taken over a period of
one year at each of the sites located at Mills Field, South San
Francisco, San Mateo, and Beresford.
"Site No. 6 (M1lls Field), the location of the present
temporary
airport is therefore recommended as a result of the
meteorological survey as the most suitable one
for the permanent
location of the San Francisco Municipal Airport.
All factors
considered,
no other suggested site appears to have as
favorable meteorological
conditions as this one.
"The present
site of the San Francisco Municipal Airport
includes a
small
portion of Site No. 4 (adjoining and
to the
south of Mills Field) and, should it become advisable to extend
the boundaries of the present airport in
a north-south direction,
the survey shows that the
Meteorological
extension
should be to
the southward.
conditions over Site No.2 (South San Francisco)
preclude extension in
that direction as they indicate more fog,
lower ceilings,
poorer visibility, higher wind velocities and
more turbulence
than are found over the present site of the
airport and the area immediately south thereof."

properties.wof:name: report: City and County of San Francisco, meteorological survey of proposed airport sites
